data.title: Historical Events on September 4
data.meta_description: Historical events for the 4th of September. See what famous, interesting and notable events happened throughout history on September 4.
data.text:
Events 1 - 200 of 209

St Boniface I ends his reign as Catholic Pope

End of the Western Roman Empire

Romulus Augustulus, last Western Roman Emperor, abdicates after forces led by Odoacer invade Rome. Traditional end of the Western Roman Empire.

Shimin becomes Emperor Taizong of Tang, Emperor of China, when his father abdicates in his favour

Aethelstan crowned King of the Anglo Saxons by the Archbishop of Canterbury at Kingston upon Thames

Battle at Montaperti, Tuscany, between rival factions the Guelphs and Ghibellines

King of Aragon Pedro III annexes Sicily

King Alfonso I of Portugal recognizes Isabella as queen of Castile

Catholic rebellion in Scotland

Hudson Discovers Manhattan

Navigator Henry Hudson is the first European to discover island of Manhattan [or Sep 11]

"Rodi" avalanche destroys Plurs, Switzerland, 1,500 killed

The Disguise of Charles II

King Charles II of England, on the run from Parliamentarians at White Ladies Priory, disguises himself as a countryman rubbing his hands and face with soot [1]

Siege of Namur

French garrison of castle Namur surrenders to the army of the Grand Alliance under the command of King William III of England

City of Amsterdam signs trade agreement with American rebels

Los Angeles is founded by 44 Spanish speaking mestizos in the Bahia de las Fumas (Bay of Smokes)

-5] William of Orange's troops plunder Netherlands towns of Hattem and Elburg

1st edition of Batavian State Courier published

North River Steamboat

Robert Fulton begins operating scheduled passenger service on his steamboat between New York and Albany

First US religious newspaper (Religious Remembrancer (Christian Observer))

Execution of José Miguel Carrera

Chilean independence figure José Miguel Carrera shot and killed after a show trial in Mendoza, Argentina

1st newsboy hired (Barney Flaherty, 10 years old by the NY Sun)

Work on Cologne cathedral recommences after a 284-year hiatus

English and French lay siege to the eastern Russian city of Petropavlovsk Kamchatsky during the Crimean war

Volt and Ohm

British Association for Advancement of Science proposes standard units of electrical measurement (the Volt after Alessandro Volta; the Ohm after Georg Ohm) at its 31st annual meeting (Manchester, England)

Maryland Campaign

General Lee begins the Maryland Campaign invading the North with 50,000 Confederate troops (US Civil war)

1862 North Beach & Mission Railway Company organized in San Francisco

Bread riots in Mobile, Alabama

The Third Republic

The Third French Republic proclaimed as French overthrow Emperor Napoleon III (who ironically was the elected president of the Second French Republic) after his defeat by Prussia at Sedan

Edison Lights Up Wall Street

In its 1st large-scale test, Thomas Edison's light bulb is used to light NY's Pearl Street Station

Britain ends its policy of penal transportation to New South Wales in Australia

1st cafeteria opens (NYC)

Geronimo Surrenders

Apache Chief Geronimo surrenders ending last major US-Indian war

Kodak Registered

George Eastman patents the first roll-film camera and registers the brand name "Kodak"

Peter Rabbit

English author Beatrix Potter first writes the story of Peter Rabbit for a 5-year-old boy

In NYC, 12,000 tailors went on strike protesting against sweat shops

8.3 earthquake shakes Yakutat Bay, Alaska

Dalai Lama signs treaty allowing British commerce in Tibet

New York Highlanders beat Boston Pilgrims, 7 - 0 and 1 - 0 for their MLB record 5th straight doubleheader sweep

French aviator Roland Garros sets world altitude record of 4,250 m (13,944 ft)

First accident (collision) in London Underground: 22 people injured

France, Russia, and Britain agree in a Pact of London that none will make a separate peace

1914 General von Moltke ceases German advance in France

Future Baseball Hall of Fame pitchers Christy Mathewson & Mordecai Brown face each other for a final time; after 25 contests Mathewson takes a 13-12 advantage with Reds 10-8 winners over Cubs

Jhr Ch Ruys de Beerenbrouck becomes 1st Dutch Catholic premier

1918 US troops land in Archangel, Russia, stay 10 months

British intervene in Petrograd

Sivas Congress

Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, who founded the Republic of Turkey, gathers a congress in Sivas to make decisions as to the future of Anatolia and Thrace.

Last day of Julian civil calendar (in parts of Bulgaria)

1920 Man o' War wins the 1 5/8-mile Lawrence Realization Stakes at Belmont Park by 100 lengths, the largest winning margin in modern thoroughbred racing history; world record time 2.40.8

World Record 2000m

Finnish super athlete Paavo Nurmi runs a 2000m world record 5:26.3 in Tampere, Finland

Swallow Sidecar Company

William Walmsley and William Lyons officially found the Swallow Sidecar Company (later Jaguar Cars) in Blackpool, England

André Charlot and Noel Coward's revue "London Calling" premieres in London

1923 Maiden flight of the first U.S. airship, the USS Shenandoah

1923 New York Yankees pitcher "Sad" Sam Jones no-hits Philadelphia A's, 2-0

Lindbergh Visits Idaho

Charles Lindbergh visits Boise, Idaho, on his cross-country tour

Cambridge Theatre opens in London

1st airplane to exceed 300 mph (483 kph), JR Wendell, Glenview, Il

Sergeants' Revolt

Coup against Cuban president Carlos Manuel de Céspedes y Quesada by Fulgencio Batista

Bradman Scores 149no

Australian cricket super-batsman Don Bradman scores 149 not out in just 104 minutes (17 fours, 4 sixes) in drawn tour match v England XI at Folkestone

British-Kenyan aviator Beryl Markham takes off from Abingdon in England on a solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean; crash-lands at Baleine Cove on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, Canada, becoming the 1st woman to make the east-west trip [1]

1936 Largo Caballero becomes Spanish premier

Swing Time

RKO Radio Pictures releases "Swing Time", directed by George Stevens, starring Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers

15-year-old cyclist Doris Kopsky becomes 1st Amateur Bicycle League of America woman's national champion in 4:22.4 in Buffalo, NY

Dutch Second Chamber affirms the Netherlands is in a State of War with Germany

1939 German troops move into Danzig

1939 Mir, a Nazi ghetto in occupied Poland, is exterminated

1939 Netherlands & Belgium declare neutrality

1939 RAF bombs Wilhelmshafen, Germany

Pioneering Plastic Surgery

Surgeon Archibald McIndoe sets up new Centre for Plastic and Jaw Surgery at Queen Victoria Hospital, East Grinstead, England to treat injured airmen

CBS begins broadcasting TV as station W2XAB

1940 Gerbrandy becomes premier of Dutch government in exile

Anton Mussert

Nazi collaborator Anton Mussert puts the fate of Netherlands in Hitler's hands

New York Yankees clinch their 3rd straight AL pennant; beat the Red Sox, 6-3; earliest date in baseball history a team has captured a flag

1941 US destroyer Greer fires on German submarine U-652

Transport #28 departs with French Jews to nazi-Germany

British 8th Army lands at Taranto, South Italy

2,087 Jews transported for Westerbork to KZ-Lower Theresienstadt

1944 British 11th Armoured Division frees Antwerp

1944 Finland breaks diplomatic contact with Nazi Germany

1944 US 1st Army frees Namur, Belgium

American chess grandmaster Reuben Fine wins 4 simultaneous rapid (10 seconds per move) games blindfolded in New York City

1945 US regains possession of Wake Island from Japan

Champion Middlesex cricket batsman Denis Compton scores 101 for South of England in tour match defeat to South Africa at Lord's; his record 17th century of the English season

Wilhelmina Abdicates

Queen Wilhelmina abdicates the Dutch throne in favour of her daughter Juliana because of illness, after 58 years, longest of any Dutch monarch

Marie Robie sinks 393 yd hole-in-one (1st hole in Furnace Brook)

"Beetle Bailey" comic strip debuts in twelve newspapers

1950 D McI Hodgson of St Ann Bay, Nova Scotia catches a 997 lb tuna

1950 First helicopter rescue of American pilot behind enemy lines

1950 Heavy typhoon strikes Japan, kills about 250

1950 NASCAR’s first paved super speedway, Darlington Raceway hosts Southern 500, first 500-mile event in NASCAR history; winner Johnny Mantz in a Plymouth

1st transcontinental TV broadcast, by US President Harry Truman

1951 NBC extends to become a 61 station coast-to-coast network

Japanese Peace Treaty Conference

US President Harry Truman addresses opening of Japanese Peace Treaty Conference

WATR (now WTXX) TV channel 20 in Waterbury, CT (NBC) begins

1953 WGEM TV channel 10 in Quincy-Hannibal, IL (NBC) begins broadcasting

Peter B. Cortese of US achieves a one-arm deadlift of 370 lbs; 22 lbs over triple his body weight, at York, Pennsylvania

Ford Motor Co. introduces Edsel automobile range

Little Rock Crisis

Governor of Arkansas, Orval Faubus, calls out National Guard to prevent 9 black students from entering a Little Rock's Central High School

-12] Hurricane Donna, kills 148 in the Caribbean & US

Radio Premiere

Carol Burnett-Richard Hayes Show premieres on CBS radio

1961 US authorizes Agency for International Development

Beatles record "How Do You Do It" at EMI Studios in London

Event of Interest

French President Charles de Gaulle visits German FR

Swissair Flight 306 crashes near Dürrenäsch, Switzerland, killing all 80 people on board

Eduardo Frei Montalva elected President of Chile

1964 NASA launches its 1st Orbital Geophysical Observatory (OGO-1)

1964 Scottish Forth Road Bridge opens (then the longest in Europe)

KREZ TV channel 6 in Durango, CO (CBS/NBC) begins broadcasting

1965 Rock group The Who's van is vandalized with $10,000 worth of equipment stolen; group was inside the Battersea Dogs Home, buying a guard dog at the time

1965 The Beatles' single "Help!" goes #1 & stays #1 for 3 weeks

Australian Jack Brabham clinches his 3rd Formula 1 World Drivers Championship with a 6th place in the Italian Grand Prix at Monza

Telethon

Jerry Lewis' 2nd Muscular Dystrophy telethon

1967 Train crash at Arnhem, Netherlands, kills 5

Nigerian troops conquer the city of Aba, Biafra during the Nigerian Civil War

-5) 29.0 cm rainfall at Workman Creek, Arizona (state record)

1970 An Irish Republican Army (IRA) member, Michael Kane (35), is killed in the premature explosion of the bomb he was planting at an electricity transformer in Belfast

Election of Interest

Marxist Salvador Allende wins a narrow plurality of votes in Chile's presidential election

1970 Russian ballerina Natalia Makarova defects to the West while on tour with the Kirov Ballet in London and is granted political asylum

Alaskan 727 crashes into Chilkoot Mountain, kills 109 (Alaska)

"The Price is Right" - US's longest running games show debuts on CBS

1972 16-year-old Ulrike Meyfarth of West Germany with a world record equalling 1.92m, wins the women's high jump gold medal at the Munich Olympics; youngest winner of individual athletics event in Olympic history

1972 American swimmer Melissa Belote with a world record 2:19.19 takes the 200m backstroke gold medal at the Munich Olympics; wraps up backstroke double having won the 100m in Olympic record time

1972 American swimmer Mike Burton sets a world record 15:52.58 to win the 1,500m gold medal at the Munich Olympics

1972 Italian diver Klaus Dibiasi wins his 2nd of 3 consecutive 10m platform gold medals the Munich Olympics

1972 John Lennon and Yoko Ono perform three songs ("Imagine"; "Now Or Never"; "Give Peace A Chance") on Jerry Lewis' 7th Muscular Dystrophy telethon at the Americana Hotel, NYC

1972 Kenyan legend Kipchoge Keino follows his 1,500m gold in Mexico City with an Olympic record 8:23.64 to win the 3,000m steeplechase at the Munich Olympics

1972 Soviet sprinter Valeriy Borzov runs 20.00 to win the men's 200m gold medal at the Munich Olympics; wraps up the 100/200m double at the Games

1972 Thieves steal 18 paintings from the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts in what was at the time the largest art theft in North America

World Record

US 4 x 100m medley relay team of Mike Stamm, Tom Bruce, Mark Spitz & Jerry Heidenreich sets world record 3:48.16 to win gold at the Munich Olympics; Mark Spitz becomes 1st athlete to win 7 Olympic gold medals at a single Games

1972 USSR performs underground nuclear test

1972 Willem Ruska of the Netherlands wins gold medals in both the heavyweight & open class Olympic judo competitions in Munich; first judoka to win 2 Olympic gold medals at one Games

William E. Colby, becomes 10th director of the CIA

Egypt and Israel sign the Sinai Interim Agreement (aka Sinai II Agreement), with the intention of peacefully resolving territorial disputes, in Geneva, Switzerland

Palestinians hijack KLM DC-9 to Cyprus

Jerry Lewis' 13th Muscular Dystrophy telethon raises $29,074,405

India need 438 to win v England, game ends at 8-429

1979 Iran army conquers Baneh

Cricket History

Sunil Gavaskar scores his third double century in Test cricket (221) to guide India to a famous draw against England in the 4th Test at The Oval

Progressive rock group Yes performs its last concert at Madison Square Garden, NYC

Longest MLB game at Fenway Park ends in 20 innings; Seattle Mariners beat Boston Red Sox, 8-7

Film & TV History

Newscaster David Brinkley is released by NBC

1981 US performs nuclear test at Nevada Test Site

Arson fire engulfs apartment-hotel in LA, 25 die

1982 USSR performs underground nuclear test

Californian skier Scott Michael Pellaton sets barefoot waterski speed record; 119.36 mph

Sports History

Greg LeMond wins UCI World Road Race Championship in 7h 01' 21" in Altenrhein, Switzerland; first American cyclist to take the title

1983 US Men's Amateur Golf Championship, North Shore CC: Jay Sigel successfully defends title 8 & 7 over Chris Perry

Music History

Nigerian singer Fela Kuti sentenced to 2 years on politically motivated charges of currency smuggling [1]

Baseball Record

NY Mets catcher Gary Carter's 2 HRs in a 9-2 win in San Diego ties MLB record of 5 HRs in 2 games

1985 Russian Igor Paklin sets new high jump world record at 2.41m in Kobe, Japan

Sports History

Mike Tyson crashes a silver BMW into a tree near Catskills NY

1988 The relocated Phoenix Cardinals play first regular-season NFL game; lose 21-14 v Bengals at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati

Jerry Lewis' 24th Muscular Dystrophy telethon raises $42,737,219

1989 Monday demonstrations demanding political reforms begin at St Nicholas's church in Leipzig, East Germany, would later be replicated around the country

Baseball Record

MLB Statistical Accuracy Committee votes to drop asterisk next to Roger Maris' 1961 home run record of 61 (passing Babe Ruth's 60) & determine an official no hitter must go at least 9 innings

The Most Happy Fella

Revival of Frank Loesser's 1956 musical "The Most Happy Fella" opens at NY State Theater, NYC, for a limited run by the New York City Opera

1991 Rte 35 Theater in Hazlit, last drive-in in NJ, closes

"Scared Silent" is 1st non news program to be seen on 3 networks simultaneously. (CBS, NBC & PBS), about child abuse hosted by Oprah

Music Concert

Singer Harry Nilsson makes a rare (and final) concert appearance, joining Ringo and His All-Starr Band for a version of his "Without You" at Caesar’s Palace. Las Vegas, Nevada

MLB New York Yankees 1-handed pitcher Jim Abbott no-hits Cleveland Indians, 4-0 at Yankee Stadium

1993 Penn State University plays its first football game in the Big 10, beating Minnesota 38-20; quarterback John Sacca throws 4 touchdown passes to Bobby Engram

Bulgarian government of Lyuben Berov falls

1994 Chinese diver Fu Mingxia wins 10m platform gold medal at World Swimming Championships in Rome, Italy; becomes first female to win back-to-back world titles in the event

1994 Kansai International airport officially opens near Osaka, Japan

NFL Record

Miami quarterback Dan Marino throws 5 touchdown passes in Dolphins' 39-35 win over New England; sets NFL record with his 18th game of 4-or-more touchdown passes

1994 Tom Tupa scores the first 2-point conversion in NFL history, running in a fake extra point attempt for the Cleveland Browns in a 28-20 win at Cincinnati

Chicago White Sox third baseman Robin Ventura hits grand slams in consecutive innings, the 4th and 5th, of a 14-3 rout of the Texas Rangers

Xena: Warrior Princess

Cult TV series "Xena: Warrior Princess" starring Lucy Lawless and Renee O'Connor debuts in the US

1995 Jerry Lewis' 30th Muscular Dystrophy telethon raises $47,800,000

1995 The Fourth World Conference on Women opens in Beijing with over 4,750 delegates from 181 countries in attendance.

Howard Stern Radio Show premieres in Louisville, Kentucky on WTFX 100.5 FM

1st ever "Who wants to be a Millionaire?" hosted by Chris Tarrant debuts on ITV in Britain

Event of Interest

Google is formally incorporated by Larry Page and Sergey Brin, two students at Stanford University

1998 NY Yankees beat Chicago White Sox, 11-6, to win their 100th game on the earliest date in MLB history besting the 1906 Chicago Cubs & 1954 Cleveland Indians by 5 days

MLB's Cincinnati Reds set a National League record with 9 home runs as they rout the Philadelphia Phillies, 22-3

Sports History

England claim first series (3-1) over West Indies since 1969; win 5th Test by 158 runs at The Oval, London; Windies captain Courtney Walsh's 132nd and final Test

After blowing an 11-run lead to Kansas City, Scott Hatteberg's bottom of the 9th walk off HR gives Oakland a historic MLB victory, 12-11; A's set AL record 20 game winning streak

2002 Argentina pulls off one of the biggest upsets in basketball history, beating the US, 87-80 in 2nd round of the World Championships; 1st US loss in 59 games since sending NBA players to international competition in 1992

Film & TV History

Before a U.S. Congressional panel, Doris Roberts testifies that age discrimination is prevalent in Hollywood

Music History

Kelly Clarkson is crowned the winner of the first series of "American Idol" TV singing competition series

Sports History

20-year-old Kyle Busch becomes youngest driver to win a NASCAR Cup Series race when he out duels Greg Biffle in the Sony HD 500 at California Speedway

Damon Allen moves past ex-CFL & NFL star Warren Moon as pro football's all-time leading passer; throws for 207 yards & 2 scores as Toronto routs Hamilton, 40-6; Allen 70,595 career passing yards

Golf Tournament

Tiger Woods matches the lowest final round of his career (8-under 63) in the Deutsche Bank C'ship at Norton, MA to win for the 5th straight time and 7th time this PGA Tour season

Canterbury earthquake: a 7.1 magnitude earthquake which struck the South Island of New Zealand at 4:35 am causing widespread damage and several power outages.

25 people are killed at a funeral suicide bombing in Nangarhar, Pakistan

2012 42 people are killed and 25 injured as a passenger bus falls down a ravine in Morocco

2012 Carpet that can help prevent falls among the elderly by warning them of unusual footsteps is developed

2012 Pauline Marois becomes the first female premier of Quebec

Aracheological remains of a Viking fortress from the 900s CE, the Vallø Borgring, is discovered in Denmark

2014 Monsoon rains begin and cause flooding over a sustained period that kills over 400 people in India & Pakistan

400-year old sunken Portuguese spice trade ship discovered near port of Cascais, Portugal

2018 Amazon becomes America's second trillion dollar company

2018 Italian city Florence bans people eating in the street in its historic center

Kaepernick's Star Rises

NFL player Colin Kaepernick who kneeled during the US national anthem is the new face of Nike's 30th anniversary advertising campaign

2018 Strongest typhoon to hit Japan in 25 years, Jebi hits Tokushima prefecture, swamping Kansai airport and killing at least 11

2018 WHO reports more than a quarter of people worldwide (1.4 billion) don't get enough physical exercise to avoid major diseases

Election of Interest

British rebel alliance of MPs vote to ban a no-deal Brexit and reject PM Boris Johnson's call for a snap election

Previous

1

2

Next
